titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Abbie Louise Bosworth Williams Collection on the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom TAM.818
titlestmt.author: Rachel Searcy

publicationstmt.publisher: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-08-20 16:48:24 -0400.

repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

did.unittitle: Abbie Louise Bosworth Williams Collection on the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom
did.abstract: Abbie Louise Bosworth Williams (1906-1983) was selected to be the delegate from the Monterey Penninsula Chapter of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom to attend the World Congress of Women in Moscow in 1963. The event included speeches, meetings, tours of other cities in the Soviet Union, and tours of factories, schools, and hospitals. Upon her return to the United States, Williams and other WILPF members were interviewed by the FBI to describe their trip and their interactions with Russians. The Abbie Louise Bosworth Williams Collection on the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom consist of materials documenting Abbie Louise Bosworth Williams's 1963 trip to the Soviet Union with the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom (WILPF). Materials include a handwritten journal (and a typed copy), maps and tourist brochures from the Soviet Union, a detailed itinerary, and notes that highlight her point of view. In addition to documenting the specific 1963 Congress, the materials in this collection more broadly documents the types of activities undertaken by the WILPF in the mid-20th century. The maps and tourist brochures of the Soviet Union and the German Democratic Republic (also known as East Germany) reflect the ways in which these countries sought to depict themselves to foreign audiences.
did.physloc: Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please request materials at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.
did.langmaterial: Correspondence and journals are in English, and publications are mostly in Russian.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Abbie Louise Bosworth Williams Collection on the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom consist of materials documenting Abbie Louise Bosworth Williams's 1963 trip to the Soviet Union with the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom (WILPF). Materials include a handwritten journal (and a typed copy), maps and tourist brochures from the Soviet Union, a detailed itinerary, and notes that highlight her point of view. In addition to documenting the specific 1963 Congress, the materials in this collection more broadly documents the types of activities undertaken by the WILPF in the mid-20th century. The maps and tourist brochures of the Soviet Union and the German Democratic Republic (also known as East Germany) reflect the ways in which these countries sought to depict themselves to foreign audiences.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection has not been arranged by an archivist. The materials are arranged in the order in which they were received from the donor.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: This collection is protected by copyright and/or related rights. You are free to use materials in the collection in any way that is permitted by the copyright and related rights legislation that applies to your use. For other uses you need to obtain permission from the rights-holder(s).

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by Alice Meyers, daughter of Abbie Louise Bosworth Williams, in November 2022; the accession number with this gift is 2022.091.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; Abbie Louise Bosworth Williams Collection on the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom; TAM 818; box number; folder number or item identifier; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: At the time of accessioning materials were rehoused in archival boxes and folders, and describes on the collection-level with a folder-level inventory.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Abbie Louise Bosworth Williams (1906-1983) was selected to be the delegate from the Monterey Penninsula Chapter of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom to attend the World Congress of Women in Moscow in 1963. The event included speeches, meetings, tours of other cities in the Soviet Union, and tours of factories, schools, and hospitals. Upon her return to the United States, Williams and other WILPF members were interviewed by the FBI to describe their trip and their interactions with Russians.
